 > This article is very interesting:
 > http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-03-2001/jw-0323-lw-jtest.html

Also from
http://www.parasoft.com/jsp/products/quick_facts.jsp?product=Jtest

<DISCLAIMER>
I have never used JTest, but have used JUnit/Ant extensively.
</DISCLAIMER>

Reading the article, it seems that JTest is a tool to allow you to 
automatically run tests on your classes.  It offers several flavors:
+ Code Convention verification.
+ "WhiteBox" testing, automatically generating test cases looking for 
unhandled Runtime Exceptions (in particular, I'd guess, NPEs).
+ Automated "BlackBox" testing using DBC language in your code: 
Automatically Generate Test classes to verify the behavior of the contract.
+ User-specified "BlackBox" testing: Allow the user to Generate new Test 
classes (and/or modify existing test classes) to excercise particular 
test cases.
+ Nightly (or on-demand) Regression Testing.

JTest will automatically run tests and save results.

JTest costs $3500 per seat.

Hmmmm...

What the article *appears* to describe to me is a $3500 JUnit with 
automation.  In particular, what I found interesting (especially 
considering the OP's thoughts about DBC vs. JUnit) (from the JTest web 
page):

 > You can add user-defined test cases by adding code to
 > automatically-generated JUnit test class templates, modifying
 > automatically-generated JUnit test classes

So JTest generates JUnit Test cases from the DBC syntax, and then runs them.

So I can pay $3500 for a tool to Automatically generate tests, allow me 
to write my own Java code to test my classes, automatically run all the 
tests, and report on the results all via a single GUI.

Or I can pay $0 for a set of tools (JUnit, Anthill, Ant) to allow me to 
write Java code to test my classes, automatically run the tests, and 
report on the results via the GUIs of my choice.

Its a tradeoff that reasonable people can disagree on.  "What's the 
value in the automatic generation of test cases?"  I know which way I 
currently lean, but that's not to say that my choice is right for everyone.

<digression>
Either way, I find the "circle" from the original posts interesting:

+ DBC made JUnit obsolete.
+ JTest was an example of a tool that implemented DBC.
+ JTest generates and runs JUnit Test Cases from DBC.
</digression>

PC
